awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Rotary Electroadhesive Clutch for Lightweight and Energy-Efficient Actuators in Next-Generation Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research project will be to enable new robotics systems with actuator hardware that is substantially lighter and less expensive than the current state-of-the-art. The high cost and limited performance of actuators are the greatest problems for engineers developing products for mobile applications, such as package delivery, security, disaster recovery, and wearable assistive devices, causing the market to bifurcate into low-cost robots with extremely limited functionality or versatile robots costing tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars. Clutches are an important way to reduce actuator requirements and costs, but conventional clutches are large, heavy, and power-hungry, ultimately negating potential improvements. In this project, we will develop an electro-adhesive clutch that is 10x lighter and uses 1000x less power than conventional clutches. This hardware innovation allows robotics engineers to use clutches with almost no mass or power consumption penalties. Removing this constraint will have a substantial impact on the commercial viability of robots that are both capable and affordable.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will consist of the design and characterization of a compact rotary electro-adhesive clutch. This work will build on recent accomplishments in creating and characterizing the linear electro-adhesive clutch design to move toward a rotary design integrating with existing robotic joints with minimal required hardware changes. The objectives of this work are to experimentally optimize the effect of materials and design choices on the performance of the rotary electro-adhesive clutch, and to establish performance metrics to evaluate the feasibility of commercial use. Design work will include simulation, mass optimization, and exploration of fabrication techniques. The experimental work will characterize the system in terms of maximum torque, power, and speed testing, response time and dissipation testing, and preliminary fatigue and wear experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The electroadhesive clutch is a high-performance robotic hardware technology initially developed at Carnegie Mellon University with NSF support. Electroadhesive clutches offer multiple key advantages to our robotics customers, enabling them to dramatically reduce the weight and power consumption of their robotic systems. The main goal of this SBIR Phase I project, Rotary Electroadhesive Clutch for Lightweight and Energy-Efficient Actuators in Next-Generation Robots (Award # 1941405), was to develop the technology from a linear proof-of-concept to a customer-ready rotary electroadhesive clutch. Not only did we create a rotary clutch that substantially outperforms conventional technology key customer-driven metrics, but we also confirmed market interest by selling multiple of these rotary clutches to robotics customers.

Our rotary electroadhesive clutch design transmits up to 34 N-m of torque, which is in the desired performance range for target customers in the exoskeleton, mobile robot, surgical robot, and human-interactive robot markets. The design is 600 times more power-efficient and is 1/3 the weight of a comparable conventional clutch. When compounded across multiple connected joints, this improvement has a dramatic cascading effect of reducing total weight and motor torque requirements across a robot. We also developed a versatile experimental testbed to gather rotary clutch performance data and enable rapid iterations of design and testing.

The Intellectual Merit of this project was generating a set of key insights regarding implementing rotary clutch designs using electroadhesive technology. This technical learning is a key milestone toward the development of a commercially available rotary electroadhesive clutch that delivers substantial performance benefits to robotics customers.

The Broader Impacts of this project will be seen across emerging robotics disciplines where weight and power consumption are crucial limiters to robot safety and operation time. Improving the safety and operation time of robotics hardware boosts the commercial viability of assistive exoskeletons, medical robots, and collaborative robots, which we view as an impactful opportunity to improve the physical wellbeing and productivity of our society.


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Stuart Diller

Image
  • The ESTAT Rotary Electroadhesive clutch designed for customers in emerging robotics markets.
    ESTAT Actuation, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Stuart Diller
    ESTAT Rotary Electroadhesive Clutch
